unnormalised: Ah, the season of nail-biting, sleepless nights, and enough anxiety to power the entire city of Mumbai – it’s exam result time! For many Indian students, the numbers on that little piece of paper (or increasingly, the digital dashboard) carry more weight than a Bollywood wedding feast. And the parents? Let's just say their expectations are higher than the Himalayas.

unnormalised: Forget the nuance of "well-rounded development" or "intrinsic motivation." In many households, it's all about the marks. 90%? Good. 95%? Excellent! 99.99%? Why not 100% beta? Sharmaji’s son got 98%, so clearly, you haven't been drinking enough Bournvita. The pressure is real, folks. And sometimes, hilariously absurd. Remember little Rohan who scored 65% in Maths? His parents grounded him from watching IPL for a whole month! Tragic.

unnormalised: Then there's the CBSE vs. ICSE saga. It's like the ongoing debate between chai and coffee, or Dhoni vs. Kohli. "CBSE is easier," some claim, "ICSE gives you a better foundation." Meanwhile, students are just trying to figure out how to score a decent CGPA (out of 10 of course) without losing their sanity. Honestly, navigating the Indian education system is more complicated than untangling a saree after Diwali.

unnormalised: And let's not even get started on the grade inflation. Back in my day (said every uncle ever), scoring 70% was considered a sign of genius. Now, if you don't have a 9 as the first digit, you might as well start preparing for a career in, I don't know, professional cricket (unless you’re already brilliant at it, obviously). A perfect example is young Priya, she scored a whopping 88% but aunty still complains about her "lost" marks.

unnormalised: But hey, amidst the stress and the parental anxieties, there's a certain charm to the whole ordeal. The collective sigh of relief when the results are finally out, the celebratory sweets (even if you only managed to score a respectable 72%), and the shared experience of surviving the academic gauntlet. And after all, numbers aren't everything, right? Except when they are…according to every Indian parent ever.
